src.utility.BlenderUtility module¶

src.utility.BlenderUtility.add_cube_based_on_bb(bouding_box, name='NewCube')[source]¶

Generates a cube based on the given bounding box, the bounding_box can be generated with our get_bounds(obj) fct.

Parameters:
  • bounding_box – bound_box [8x[3xfloat]], with 8 vertices for each corner
  • name – name of the new cube

:return the generated object

src.utility.BlenderUtility.add_object_only_with_direction_vectors(vertices, normals, radius=1.0, name='NewDirectionObject')[source]¶

Generates a new object with the given vertices, no edges or faces are generated.

Parameters:
  • vertices – [[float, float, float]] list of vertices
  • name – str name of the new object

:return the generated obj

src.utility.BlenderUtility.add_object_only_with_vertices(vertices, name='NewVertexObject')[source]¶

Generates a new object with the given vertices, no edges or faces are generated.

Parameters:
  • vertices – [[float, float, float]] list of vertices
  • name – str name of the new object

:return the generated obj

src.utility.BlenderUtility.check_bb_intersection(obj1, obj2)[source]¶
Checks if there is a bounding box collision, these don’t have to be axis-aligned, but if they are not:
The surrounding/including axis-aligned bounding box is calculated and used to check the intersection
Parameters:
  • obj1 – object 1 to check for intersection, must be a mesh
  • obj2 – object 2 to check for intersection, must be a mesh

returns a boolean

src.utility.BlenderUtility.check_if_uv_coordinates_are_set(obj: bpy_types.Object)[source]¶
Parameters:obj – should be an object, which has a mesh
src.utility.BlenderUtility.check_intersection(obj, obj2, cache=None)[source]¶
Checks if the two objects are colliding, the code is from:
https://blender.stackexchange.com/questions/9073/how-to-check-if-two-meshes-intersect-in-python

The check is performed along the edges from the object, which has less edges.

Parameters:
  • obj1 – object 1 to check for intersection, must be a mesh
  • obj2 – object 2 to check for intersection, must be a mesh

returns a boolean and the cache of the objects, which already have been triangulated

src.utility.BlenderUtility.duplicate_objects(objects)[source]¶

Creates duplicates of objects, first duplicates are given name <orignial_object_name>.001

Parameters:objects – an object or a list of objects to be duplicated
Returns:a list of objects
src.utility.BlenderUtility.get_all_materials()[source]¶

Returns a list of all materials used and unused :return: a list of all materials

src.utility.BlenderUtility.get_all_mesh_objects()[source]¶

Returns a list of all mesh objects in the scene :return: a list of all mesh objects

src.utility.BlenderUtility.get_all_textures()[source]¶

Returns a list of all textures. :return: All textures. Type: list.

src.utility.BlenderUtility.get_bound_volume(obj)[source]¶

Gets the volume of a possible orientated bounding box. :param obj: Mesh object. :return: volume of a bounding box.

src.utility.BlenderUtility.get_bounds(obj)[source]¶
Parameters:obj – a mesh object

:returns [8x[3xfloat]] the object aligned bounding box coordinates in world coordinates

src.utility.BlenderUtility.load_image(file_path, num_channels=3)[source]¶

Load the image at the given path returns its pixels as a numpy array.

The alpha channel is neglected.

Parameters:
  • file_path – The path to the image.
  • num_channels – Number of channels to return.
Returns:

The numpy array
src.utility.BlenderUtility.local_to_world(cords, world)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • cords – coordinates a tuple of 3 values for x,y,z
  • world – world matrix <- transformation matrix

Returns a cords transformed to the given transformation world matrix

src.utility.BlenderUtility.triangulate(obj, transform=True, triangulate=True, apply_modifiers=False)[source]¶
Obj:object to triangulate, must be a mesh
Transform:transform to world coordinates if True
Triangulate:perform triangulation if True
Apply_modifiers:
 applies modifiers if any and True

Returns a transformed, triangulated copy of the mesh (much smaller in size and can be used for quicker maths)

src.utility.BlenderUtility.vector_to_euler(vector, vector_type)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • vector – UP (for MESH objs) of FORWARD (for LIGHT/CAMERA objs) vector. Type: mathutils Vector.
  • vector_type – Type of an input vector: UP or FORWARD. Type: string.
Returns:

Corresponding Euler angles XYZ-triplet. Type: mathutils Euler.
